occurrences.line_text: And lastly throwne themselues into these heauy stowres.
And thrilling sorrow throwne his vtmost dart;
Had throwne to ground the vnregarded right:
And throwne about the cliffs. Arriued there,
And widow-like sad wimple throwne away,
Throwne out from womanish impatient mind?
It was auoided quite, and throwne out priuily.
The light goes out, and weeke is throwne away;
Is throwne on the Rich strond:
A little off, his shield was rudely throwne,
But that same younker soone was ouer throwne,
Throwne out by angry Ioue in his vengeance,
Thine honor sau'd, though into thraldome throwne?
Were throwne by Pyrrha and Deucalione:
But hauing from his courser her downe throwne,
And throwne it vp vnto my brothers share:
But for this threasure throwne vppon his strand;
But that the sea hath it vnto me throwne?
Fellow of this I beare, throwne not in vaine,
He with strong hand down fro[m] his steed me throw'th,
To take the ayre, and heare the thrushes song,
Then rudely he him thrust, and pusht with paine,
The bleeding bough did thrust into the ground,
But vnto hell did thrust him downe aliue,
Is not enough, that thrust from heauen dew
But thrust them forth still, as they wexed old:
Of glorious knighthood, after bloud to thrust,
Approching, first the Hag did thrust away,
Then on his brest his victour foote he thrust:
And him that raignd, into his rowme thrust downe,
From whence the gods haue her for enuy thrust:
His poinant speare he thrust with puissant sway
And brutish shape thrust downe to hell below,
Did thrust the shallop from the floting strand:
Where ill became him, rashly would haue thrust,
The winged boy did thrust into his throne,
He thrust, and smote downe all that was betweene,
Thrust to an Hynd within some couert glade,
I will thrust downe into the deepest maine,
But he the right from thence did thrust away,
Me like a dog she out of dores did thrust,
Vnder her wombe his fatall sword he thrust,
Vpon him ran, and thrust it all attone
To thrust him out of dore, doing his worst assay.
Of his rich mould, did thrust it farre away,
Who thrusting boldly twixt him and the blow,
And thrusting fierce into the thickest preace,
With that he thrusts into the thickest throng,
Would thumpe her forward, and inforce to goe,
And many feete fast thumping th'hollow ground,
To thunder blowes, and fiersly to assaile
Seemd that lowde thunder with amazement great
Weening it had beene thunder in the skie,
That now I weene Ioues dreaded thunder light
Ne shield defend the thunder of his throwes:
A bridge of bras, whose sound heaue[n]s thunder seem'd to bee.
Seemed to thunder, and did nigh affray
His stolen steed to thunder furiously,
That through she passed; as a thunder bolt
With dreadfull thunder and lightning atwixt,
And fire did flash, like lightning after thunder,
With flashing thunderbolt ywounded sore:
It booted nought, to thinke, such thunderbolts to beare.
Armd with his thunderbolts and lightning fire,
Frame thunderbolts for Ioues auengefull threate.
And doubled strokes, like dreaded thunders threat:
Doe all attonce their thunders rage forth rent,
He hewd, and lasht, and foynd, and thundred blowes,
And thundred strokes thereon so hideouslie,
The tyrant thundred his thicke blowes so fast,
And thundring Ioue, that high in heauen doth dwell,
The wrath of thundring Ioue, that rules both night and day?
With thundring noyse, and all the ayre doth choke,
Hurles forth his thundring dart with deadly food,
And with big thundring voyce reuyld him lowd;
On goodly courser thundring with his feet,
Ne swelling Neptune, ne loud thundring Ioue
Therein was writ, how often thundring Ioue
By thundring Ioue in the Phlegrean plaine.
Hauing all satisfide their bloudy thurst,
To seeke young men, to quench her flaming thurst,
Of needments at his backe. Thus as they past,
Led with delight, they thus beguile the way,
Thus ill bestedd, and fearefull more of shame,
The drouping Night thus creepeth on them fast,
Thus well instructed, to their worke they hast,
Or the blind God, that doth me thus amate,
Yet thus perforce he bids me do, or die.
Why Dame (quoth he) what hath ye thus dismayd?
Melting in teares, then gan she thus lament;
Long time they thus together traueiled,
And doubting much his sence, he thus bespake;
Hath thus transformd, and plast in open plaines,
Art thou misshaped thus, as now I see?
Long she thus traueiled through deserts wyde,
Thus long the dore with rage and threats he bet,
Where haue ye bene thus long out of my sight?
And heauenly virgin thus outraged see,
To dally thus with death, is no fit toy,
Then gan the Pilgrim thus, I chaunst this day,
Then gins her grieued ghost thus to lament and mourne.
Whiles thus I heare you of your sorrowes treat.
They sadly traueild thus, vntill they came
And with sweet ioyous cheare him thus bespake;
That of your selfe ye thus berobbed arre,
Thus when they had the witch disrobed quight,
Thus as he spake, his visage wexed pale,
Till gentle Vna thus to him gan say;
Thus beene they parted, Arthur on his way
Sir knight, aread who hath ye thus arayd,
What franticke fit (quoth he) hath thus distraught
Thus as they gan of sundry things deuise,
Then Vna thus; But she your sister deare;
Whom thus recouer'd by wise Patience,
And in her modest manner thus bespake;
Thus flocked all the folke him round about,
Thus gan to say. But eare he thus had said,
Thus gan to say. But eare he thus had said,
Which he disclosing, red thus, as the paper spake.
At last his solemne silence thus he brake,
With sober countenaunce thus to him sayd;
Thus when that Princes wrath was pacifide,
The which O pardon me thus to enfold
To them approching, thus the knight bespake:
The knight approching nigh thus to her said,
Great pittie is to see you thus dismaid,
Did thus reuest, and deckt with due habiliments.
To see the Redcrosse thus aduaunced hye;
Thus fowle to hasten your vntimely date;
This lucklesse child, whom thus ye see with bloud defild.
My lifest Lord she thus beguiled had;
With cup thus charmd, him parting she deceiu'd;
Thus when Sir Guyon with his faithfull guide
Such is the state of men: thus enter wee
Whom thus at gaze, the Palmer gan to bord
With goodly reason, and thus faire bespake;
Whilest she her selfe thus busily did frame,
Whilst thus they mingled were in furious armes,
Thus fairely she attempered her feast,
Great fauour I thee graunt, for aunswere thus to stay.
Thus said; Old man, great sure shalbe thy meed,
When she at last him spying thus bespake;
To whom she thus; but ere her words ensewed,
To whom he thus: ï¿½ fairest vnder skie,
Thus when as Guyon Furor had captiu'd,
He woo'd her thus: Pryene (so she hight)
Thus lowly to abase thy beautie bright,
Thus heaping crime on crime, and griefe on griefe,
When he thus ended had his sorrowing,
Then gan the Palmer thus, most wretched man,
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
Wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue do thus expell:
But sparks, seed, drops, and filth do thus delay;
Thus as he spake, lo far away they spyde
With silly weake old woman thus to fight.
And all enraged, thus him loudly shent;
That hath (maugre her spight) thus low me laid in dust.
Sir Knight, that thus ye now subdewed arre:
Thus in still waues of deepe delight to wade,
Whiles thus she talked, and whiles thus she toyd,
Whiles thus she talked, and whiles thus she toyd,
Thus when she had his eyes and senses fed
The whiles with a loue lay she thus him sweetly charm'd.
Thus to mislead me, whiles I you obaid:
That art thus foully fled from famous enemie?
Whiles thus they strugled in that idle waue,
Furor, oh Furor hath me thus bedight:
Till that him thus bespake their soueraigne Lord & sire.
Who groning deepe, thus answerd him againe;
Who lifting vp his head, him answerd thus:
To proue he liued ill, that did thus foully dye.
Thus for to blot the honour of the dead,
Bad therefore I him deeme, that thus lies dead on field.
Tho turning to those brethren, thus bespoke,
The guilt, which if he liued had thus long,
Long trembling still he stood: at last thus sayd;
As to the Patrone of his life, thus sayd;
To whom the Infant thus, Faire Sir, what need
Thus as he spoke, loe with outragious cry
Thus when they had that troublous rout disperst,
Gentle Madame, why beene ye thus dismaid,
Liues any, that you hath thus ill apaid?
Thus they awhile with court and goodly game,
Thus Brute this Realme vnto his rule subdewd,
Their aged Syre, thus eased of his crowne,
Beguild thus with delight of nouelties,
Thus these twelue troupes with dreadfull puissance
And halfe in rage, to be deluded thus,
Thus now alone he conquerour remaines;
Thus said; Behold th'ensamples in our sights,
When them the wary Boateman thus bespake;
Their pleasaunt tunes they sweetly thus applide;
Thus being entred, they behold around
When thus the Palmer; Now Sir, well auise;
Whom this Enchauntresse hath transformed thus,
To whom the Palmer thus, The donghill kind
Thus farre forth pardon, sith that choicest wit
Thus reconcilement was betweene them knit,
Long they thus trauelled in friendly wise,
At last the passion past she thus him answered.
And thus replide, How euer, Sir, ye file
The Damzell pauzd, and then thus fearefully;
As it an Earth-quake were; at last she thus bespake.
Then Glauce thus, Let not it thee offend,
That we thus rashly through thy darkesome dore,
He bad tell on; and then she thus began.
Ne ye faire Britomartis, thus arayd,
And then his spirite thus gan forth display;
Then Merlin thus; Indeed the fates are firme,
Whiles thus thy Britons do in languour pine,
And sighing sore, at length him thus bespake;
Conceiu'd a bold deuise, and thus bespake;
Thus when she had the virgin all arayd,
Thereat she sighed deepe, and after thus complaynd.
Thus as she her recomforted, she spyde,
She shortly thus; Fly they, that need to fly;
Whiles thus he lay in deadly stonishment,
Thus much afford me, ere that he did die
Thus when they all had sorrowed their fill,
Thus did the Prince that wearie night outweare,
That through this forest wandreth thus alone;
And of his lucklesse lot and cruell loue thus plaind.
Thus warreid he long time against his will,
To whom halfe weeping, she thus answered,
Thus as he led the Beast along the way,
Long thus I woo'd her with dew obseruance,
Thus am I hopelesse euer to attaine
Him shaped thus, she deckt in garments gay,
Thus as they two of kindnesse treated long,
It fortuned, whilest thus she stifly stroue,
Whiles thus we suffer this same dotard old,
Who louers will deceiue. Thus was the ape,
Him to commend to her, thus spake, of all well eyde.
Then sighing soft awhile, at last she thus:
Thus finely did he his false nets dispred,
Thus whilest all things in troublous vprore were,
Long thus he chawd the cud of inward griefe,
At last he thus; Thou clod of vilest clay,
Thus long they three together traueiled,
And hatefull outrage long him chaced thus;
Fit medcine to his griefe, and spake thus courtesly.
Thus she at length perswaded him to rise,
And turning backe to Scudamour, thus sayd;
Whiles thus on earth great Ioue these pageaunts playd,
And scoffing, thus vnto his mother sayd,
And vnderneath his feet was written thus,
Ouer the dore thus written she did spye
Thus she there waited vntill euentyde,
Thus marched these sixe couples forth in faire degree.
Thus doe those louers with sweet counteruayle,
Lo thus they rode, till at the last they spide
For thy, he thus to Paridel bespake,
So false Duessa, but vile Ate thus;
But being past, he thus began amaine;
With whom as they thus rode accompanide,
Sir knight why ride ye dumpish thus behind,
He made him open chalenge, and thus boldly sayd.
And lowly to her lowting thus behight;
All full of wrath, thus fiercely him bespake;
Herein, as thus. It lately so befell,
Thus as they marched all in close disguise,
That I thy labours lost may thus reuiue,
And charging him a fresh thus felly him bespake.
Haue I thus long thy life vnto thee let:
Thus did the battell varie to and fro,
Whilst thus the case in doubtfull ballance hong,
Thus whilest their minds were doubtfully distraught,
Thus when they all accorded goodly were,
But Cambell thus did shut vp all in iest,
Thus was Sir Satyrane with all his band
This being ended thus, and all agreed,
He lowdly gan to laugh, and thus to iest;
He wondred much. But th'other thus can say;
Whereto thus Scudamour, Small harme it were
That thus he sharply sayd; Now by my head,
Whiles thus they communed, lo farre away
Thus long they trac'd, and trauerst to and fro,
He thus bespake; Certes Sir Artegall,
When Glauce thus gan wisely all vpknit;
Her thus bespake; But Sir without offence
To whom thus Britomart, Certes Sir knight,
Till Glauce thus; Faire Sir, be nought dismayd
Till Britomart him fairely thus behight;
To whom thus aunswer'd was: Ah wretched wight
Thus of their euils as they did discourse,
Whilest thus in battell they embusied were,
Thus long this gentle bird to him did vse,
That being mou'd with ruth she thus bespake.
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
And sighing inly deepe, her thus bespake;
For thus conuersing with this noble Knight;
All which was thus to him declared by that Squire.
Thus as they talked, loe where nigh at hand
But what mishap thus long him fro my selfe remoues?
Thus gazing long, at them much wondred he,
Thus when the Prince had perfectly compylde
Thus many miles they two together wore,
Thus they long while continued in fight,
To whom the Prince thus goodly well replied;
But Scudamour then sighing deepe, thus saide,
But thus turmoild from one to other stowre,
That liuing thus, a wretch and louing so,
Then good sir Claribell him thus bespake,
Thus hauing past all perill, I was come
Into the inmost Temple thus I came,
But thus brake forth, that all the temple it did fill.
Whilest thus I spake, behold with happy eye
Thus sate they all a round in seemely rate:
To whom I thus, Nay but it fitteth best,
Thus safely with my loue I thence did wend.
Bvt ah for pittie that I haue thus long
She gan afresh thus to renew her wretched case.
Thus whilst his stony heart with tender ruth
To whom God Neptune softly smyling, thus;
Thus she him trayned, and thus she him taught,
Thus she him trayned, and thus she him taught,
And thus vnto him spake, without regard or feare;
It fortun'd whylest they were thus ill beset,
Whilest thus they busied were bout Florimell,
Now when these counterfeits were thus vncased
Whilest thus amidst the billowes beating of her
When they thus ended had, the Knight began;
Then Artegall thus to the younger sayd;
Then turning to the elder thus he sayd;
When he his sentence thus pronounced had,
Whom soone as he beheld, he knew, and thus behight.
But onely thus; Most haplesse well ye may
When thus the field was voided all away,
Her name was Clarin, and thus to her sayd;
Hauing her thus disarmed of her shield,
Thus there long while continu'd Artegall,
And to her turning, thus began againe;
And with wide glauncing words, one day she thus him proued.
I rew that thus thy better dayes are drowned
She feeling him thus bite vpon the bayt,
She thus oft times was beating off and on,
For seeking thus to salue the Amazon,
With which he dares our offers thus despize.
Yet thus much friendship she to him did show,
Thus he long while in thraldome there remayned,
Till she againe thus sayd; Talus be bold,
To whom he thus at length. The tidings sad,
So as she thus melancholicke did ride,
Thus passing th'euening well, till time of rest,
Thus did she watch, and weare the weary night
Thus she all night wore out in watchfulnesse,
Therefore thus one of them, who seem'd in sight
So fild with heauenly fury, thus he her behight.
And thus vpbrayding sayd; This token beare
Thus answer'd; Lewdly thou my loue deprauest,
They stayd their hands, when she thus gan to speake;
Ah gentle Knights, what meane ye thus vnwise
That all vnweeting haue you wrong'd thus sore,
To whom she thus; Then wote ye well, that I
Thus goe they both together to their geare,
Thus long they trast, and trauerst to and fro,
To which when she approched, thus she sayd;
Thus there he stood, whylest high ouer his head,
Thus she did sit in souerayne Maiestie,
Thus did she sit in royall rich estate,
Him thus bespake; O most redoubted Knight
Sith ye thus farre haue tendred my poore case,
Whom by his name saluting, thus he gan;
To whom he thus; She liueth sure and sound;
Then thus replide; Now sure and by my life,
For from the day that he thus did it leaue,
Whom when they thus distressed did behold,
To whom he thus; My name is Burbon hight,
To whom thus Artegall; Certes Sir knight,
When Calidore thus first; Haile noblest Knight
But first him losde, and afterwards thus to him saide.
To whom he answerd thus; My haplesse case
Thus whiles they spake, they heard a ruefull shrieke
And with sterne count'naunce thus vnto him spake.
Yet answerd thus; Not vnto me the shame,
More then his loue, which thus ye seeke t'obtaine.
Wherewith all full of wrath, she thus replyde;
Thus long they trac'd and trauerst to and fro,
With goodly patience, thus he to him sayd;
Ne surely thus vnarm'd I likely were;
To whom then thus the noble youth; May be
Into this land, where I haue wond thus long,
And thus replide; Faire chyld, the high desire
Thus when they long had treated to and fro,
Then speaking to the Ladie, thus he sayd:
To tell, what cruell hand hath thus arayd
He her not finding, both them thus nigh dead did leaue.
Him thus describ'd, to be of stature large,
Which when as he perceiu'd, he thus bespake;
Whom Calidore thus carried on his chine,
Thus hauing her restored trustily,
Caught her thus loosely wandring here and there,
Thus whilest he was in this distressed case,
That doth thus strongly ward the Castle of the ford.
Whom when as he thus combred did behold,
Her chearing vp, thus gently to her sayd;
What be you wofull Dame, which thus lament,
To whom she thus, What need me Sir to tell,
Then thus began the lamentable Dame;
For which I thus doe mourne, and poure forth ceaselesse teares.
And hauing cheared her, thus said; faire Dame,
Bout which whilest he was busied thus hard,
Him thus bespake; My liefe, my lifes desire,
Why haue ye me alone thus long yleft?
Hath you thus long away from me bereft?
To whom she thus; I am, as now ye see,
And thus he to them sayd; Faire daughter Dame,
And you faire sonne, which here thus long now lie
Thus hauing sayd, his sickely patients
And with reprochfull words him thus bespake on hight;
There whilest he thus was setling things aboue,
Thus hauing all things well in peace ordayned,
Then thus said he, There is a straunger knight,
Yet thus at length he said, How now Sir Knight?
Thus whylest they were debating diuerslie,
And to the Prince thus sayd; See you Sir Knight,
With which approching, thus he gan to say;
Her tongue to her restord, then thus she sayd;
Thus I triumphed long in louers paine,
This bottle thus before you with such toile,
And let him rise. Then thus the Prince gan say;
Now Lady sith your fortunes thus dispose,
Long thus she fled, till that at last she thought
Whylest thus he talkt, the knight with greedy eare
He thus replyde; Now surely syre, I find,
And thus bespake; Sir knight, your bounteous proffe[r]
Thus did the gentle knight himselfe abeare
Thus Calidore continu'd there long time,
And first him greeting, thus vnto him spake;
Tho gan that shepheard thus for to dilate;
When thus that shepherd ended had his speach,
Thus to bereaue thy Loues deare sight from thee:
Thus did the courteous Knight excuse his blame,
Whylest thus she in these hellish dens remayned,
During which space that she thus sicke did lie,
Thus as they words amongst them multiply,
He thus began: Where shall I then commence
Sir Calidore when thus he now had raught
Thus long continu'd Claribell a thrall,
There they a while together thus did dwell
Thus was this Monster by the maystring might
Sometimes a thwart, sometimes he strooke him strayt,
Or helpe himselfe, and laying thwart her horse,
Yet whether thwart or flatly it did lyte,
Thy weaker Nouice to performe thy will,
Thy weaker Nouice to performe thy will,
Faire Venus sonne, that with thy cruell dart
Lay now thy deadly Heben bow apart,
And with thy mother milde come to mine ayde:
Shed thy faire beames into my feeble eyne,
That keepes thy body from the bitter fit;
And hide thy head. Therewith vpon his crest
Enough is, that thy foe doth vanquisht stand
Now at thy mercy: Mercie not withstand:
In choice, and change of thy deare loued Dame,
And rash misweening doe thy hart remoue:
Lo his Fidessa to thy secret faith I flye.
Whilest here thy shield is hangd for victors hyre,
And sluggish german doest thy forces slake,
Thy selfe thy message doe to german deare,
Thy selfe thy message doe to german deare,
Goe say, his foe thy shield with his doth beare.
Why suffredst thou thy Nephewes deare to fall
Go gather vp the reliques of thy race,
Of great Apollo, shew thy famous might
Thy guilty wrong, or else thee guilty yield.
In euill houre thy foes thee hither sent,
Anothers wrongs to wreake vpon thy selfe:
Hath thee incenst, to hast thy dolefull fate?
Here take thy louers token on thy pate.
Here take thy louers token on thy pate.
O hold thy mortall hand for Ladies sake,
And me thy worthy meed vnto thy Leman take.
And me thy worthy meed vnto thy Leman take.
Henceforth thy hated face for euer hyde,
Thy sad tongue cannot tell more heauy plight,
Ah Loue, lay downe thy bow, the whiles I may respire.
Defend thine honour, and thy foes confound:
Vpon the banke, yet wilt thy selfe not passe the flood?
Is not enough thy euill life forespent?
But here lie downe, and to thy rest betake,
If in true ballance thou wilt weigh thy state:
Thy life shut vp, for death so oft did call;
And though good lucke prolonged hath thy date,
To draw thy dayes forth to their last degree?
Is not the measure of thy sinfull hire
Thou falsed hast thy faith with periurie,
And sold thy selfe to serue Duessa vilde,
With whom in all abuse thou hast thy selfe defilde?
Shall he thy sins vp in his knowledge fold,
Ne let vaine words bewitch thy manly hart,
Ne diuelish thoughts dismay thy constant spright.
Whereon thy innocent feet doe euer tread,
That to redeeme thy woefull parents head,
Yet ceasest not thy wearie soles to lead,
Or doen thy feeble feet vnweeting hither stray?
Thy selfe to see, and tyred limbs to rest,
Led with thy prayses and broad-blazed fame,
Whereof the keyes are to thy hand behight
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
